importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the drone attacks on Khartoum airport, just one day before its scheduled reopening, highlights a critical moment in Sudan’s post-conflict recovery and security.
The start of the fighting between the Sudanese army and the RSF that led to the closure of Khartoum international airport, marking the beginning of the protracted conflict.
The day before the reported drone attacks, when the Sudan Civil Aviation Authority announced the gradual resumption of domestic flights, indicating a fragile return to normalcy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The three-day period of drone attacks in seven days indicates a rising pattern of RSF aggression, undermining confidence in the security of key infrastructure and civilian life in Khartoum.
The recent escalation of drone attacks, including on military bases and the airport, signals a destabilizing phase in Sudan's post-reoccupation recovery efforts.

keyTakeAways: Drone attacks on Khartoum international airport, including near the airport perimeter, have delayed its reopening just one day before scheduled resumption.
The attacks, reported to use 'suicide drones', are attributed to the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which has repeatedly targeted military and civilian infrastructure.
Despite the Sudanese army reclaiming control of Khartoum earlier in 2025, drone attacks have continued, indicating ongoing instability and resistance.
The RSF’s control over parts of Darfur, including their attempt to seize el-Fasher, threatens regional balance and could lead to ethnic-based violence and further displacement.
The wider Sudan conflict has caused tens of thousands of deaths, displaced nearly 12 million people, and created the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises.
The reconstruction of Khartoum and return of government officials to the capital have been hampered by frequent power outages and drone threats.
Multiple reports from AFP, Sudan Tribune, and local media confirm the attacks and their impact, though no group has claimed responsibility yet.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A series of drone attacks, attributed to the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), targeted Khartoum international airport and other areas in Sudan’s capital just one day before its long-awaited reopening. The attacks, which included more than eight blasts and the use of 'suicide drones', have severely disrupted efforts to resume domestic flights and undermined confidence in the country’s recovery. Despite the Sudanese army reclaiming control of Khartoum earlier in 2025, the RSF continues to launch attacks on military installations and civilian infrastructure, including Omdurman. These strikes reflect broader instability, with the RSF attempting to seize el-Fasher in Darfur—a move that could trigger ethnic violence and further displacement. The wider conflict has already killed tens of thousands and displaced nearly 12 million people, creating the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises. The Sudan Civil Aviation Authority has announced a gradual return of flights, but the threat to key infrastructure remains a major concern for national stability and humanitarian recovery.
title: Drone attack in Sudan threatens Khartoum airport’s reopening: Reports
